JPO Sudirman Tak Beratap, Ini Kata Warga yang Pro dan Kontra
07 Nov 2019, 02:26 by Antara, Ninis Chairunnisa
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Pemerintah DKI Jakarta memutuskan melepas atap di Jembatan Penyeberangan Orang atau JPO yang terletak di Jalan Jendral Sudirman menuai pro dan kontra. Atap JPO Sudirman itu dilepas sejak Selasa, 5 November 2019.
Salah satu pejalan kaki yang merasa keberatan adalah Panji. Menurut dia, dihilangkannya atap itu membuat perjalanan lebih melelahkan karena terpapar panas.
"Kalau bener-bener tengah siang mau nyari makannya jadi kerasa banget capeknya karena harus menghadapi langsung terik matahari yang kebangetan. Menurut saya jadi aneh aja sih," kata Panji yang sering menggunakan JPO Sudirman dan bekerja di salah satu gedung perkantoran dekat JPO itu, Rabu, 6 November 2019.
Senada dengan Panji, Henny juga menilai pencopotan atap JPO itu tidak efektif. "Kalau kata saya sih balikin aja ini atapnya tolong. Kalau pagi sampai siang kepanasan, terus kalau hujan susah enggak bisa neduh. Jadi makin sulit buat jalan," kata dia.
Menurut Henny, jika alasan Dinas Bina Marga DKI ingin menjadikan JPO Sudirman menjadi 'instagramable' dengan mencopot atapnya, justru merugikan pejalan kaki yang sering menggunakan fasilitas umum itu. "Saya baca berita, katanya mau dibikin instagramable dipasang lampu-lampu dari bawah jembatan. Pekerja juga sudah pada pulang pasti, enggak efektif iya kan?" kata dia.
Meski begitu, ada juga yang sepakat dengan pelepasan atap JPO itu. Budi Darsono sebagai salah satu pejalan kaki menyambut antusias langkah pembongkaran atap itu sebagai inovasi. "Buat saya sih jadi oke. Kayak jadi terbuka gitu pandangan kita enggak ketutup. Mungkin karena saya suka foto juga buat saya kalau malam jadi dapat pencahayaan lebih banyak," kata dia.
Budi menilai tidak ada perbedaan besar antara JPO yang terbuka dan tertutup karena fungsi JPO hanya menghubungkan dua jalur trotoar yang terbuka. "Beda cerita kalau ini penghubung antar gedung tapi malah kebuka, itu baru masalah," ujarnya.
Berdasarkan pantauan Antara, pada Rabu sore hingga pukul 18.00 WIB, masyarakat masih banyak yang melintasi JPO Sudirman dengan atap yang sudah terbuka. Tepi pagar sisi kanan- kirinya terlihat mengkilap karena baru dicat berwarna perak. Namun saat hujan turun, masyarakat langsung berlarian dan seketika JPO Sudirman yang tak beratap pun terlihat sepi dari pejalan kaki.
Dinas Bina Marga DKI memberi penjelasan pencopotan atap JPO Sudirman dilakukan karena Pemprov akan menata ulang JPO yang tampak kusam itu dengan penataan yang mengedepankan estetika.

JPO Sudirman Is Not Covered, These Are Pro and Cons Residents Said
Nov 7 2019, 02:26 by Antara, Ninis Chairunnisa
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - The DKI Jakarta Government has decided to remove the roof on the People's Crossing Bridge or JPO which is located on Jalan Jendral Sudirman, reaping the pros and cons. The roof of JPO Sudirman was released since Tuesday, 5 November 2019.
One of the pedestrians who objected was Panji. According to him, the removal of the roof made the journey more tiring because of exposure to heat.
"If you really want to look for lunch in the middle of the day, it feels really tired because you have to face the direct heat in the sun. I think it's just weird," said Panji, who often uses JPO Sudirman and works in one of the office buildings near JPO, Wednesday. , 6 November 2019.
In line with Panji, Henny also considered that the removal of the JPO roof was ineffective. "If I say just turn it over, the roof please. If it gets hot from morning until noon, then if it's hard to rain it won't be able to shade. So it will be harder to walk," he said.
According to Henny, if the excuse of the DKI Jakarta Bina Marga Office wants to make JPO Sudirman into an 'instagramable' by removing the roof, it will harm pedestrians who often use public facilities. "I read the news, he said that he wanted to make it instagramable to install lights from under the bridge. The workers have also returned home for sure, not effective, right?" he said.
Even so, there are those who agree with the removal of the JPO roof. Budi Darsono as one of the pedestrians enthusiastically welcomed the dismantling of the roof as an innovation. "For me, it's okay. Like it's open, our view isn't closed. Maybe it's because I like photos too for me, when the night gets more lighting," he said.
Budi believes there is no big difference between open and closed JPOs because the JPO function only connects two open sidewalks. "It's a different story if this is a liaison between buildings but instead it opens, that's just a problem," he said.
Based on the observation of Antara, on Wednesday afternoon until 18:00 WIB, many people still crossed the Sudirman JPO with an open roof. The edges of the fence on the right and left sides were shiny because they had just been painted silver. But when it rained, the people immediately ran and immediately the Sudirman JPO which was not roofed was seen quiet from pedestrians.
The DKI Jakarta Bina Marga Office explained Sudopo's roof removal was carried out because the provincial government would rearrange the dull looking JPO with an aesthetic arrangement.
